guide.introduction: Here I am going to show you how to fold a 2-compartment/pocket letter holder through some basic origami folds. This is an easy project so even kids can do it and organize their things better.
guide.introduction_rendered: Here I am going to show you how to fold a 2-compartment/pocket letter holder through some basic origami folds. This is an easy project so even kids can do it and organize their things better.

lines.text: Things Needed
lines.text_raw: '''Things Needed'''

lines.text: Handmade paper 23” x 30” [any thick paper will do]
lines.text_raw: Handmade paper 23” x 30” [any thick paper will do]

lines.text: Double Tape
lines.text_raw: Double Tape

lines.text: Ruler or Measuring Tape
lines.text_raw: Ruler or Measuring Tape

lines.text: Marker
lines.text_raw: Marker

lines.text: Measurements
lines.text_raw: '''Measurements'''

lines.text: Firstly, take a look at the letters/envelopes lying around in your house to get an idea of how deep the compartments/pockets should be.
lines.text_raw: Firstly, take a look at the letters/envelopes lying around in your house to get an idea of how deep the compartments/pockets should be.

lines.text: With some experimentation I found that pockets with a depth equal to half the length of the letters/envelopes will hold them best.
lines.text_raw: With some experimentation I found that pockets with a depth equal to half the length of the letters/envelopes will hold them best.

lines.text: I decided to make the top pocket for the bigger letters/envelopes and the lower pocket for the smaller ones.
lines.text_raw: I decided to make the top pocket for the bigger letters/envelopes and the lower pocket for the smaller ones.

lines.text: Smaller letters/envelopes are of size 6” [approx.] and bigger ones are 8” [approx.].
lines.text_raw: Smaller letters/envelopes are of size 6” [approx.] and bigger ones are 8” [approx.].

lines.text: Mark and Fold the paper
lines.text_raw: '''Mark and Fold the paper'''

lines.text: Basically, by doing fan-folds on the paper length-wise we should be able to get the basic form in shape. Fan-folds are nothing but alternate mountain & valley folds.
lines.text_raw: Basically, by doing fan-folds on the paper length-wise we should be able to get the basic form in shape. Fan-folds are nothing but alternate mountain & valley folds.

lines.text: For the given sizes of letter/envelope, mark the points at the given distances along the length of the paper.
lines.text_raw: For the given sizes of letter/envelope, mark the points at the given distances along the length of the paper.

lines.text: Make the mountain folds at 6" & 17" along the length of the paper (measurements are from the base).
lines.text_raw: Make the mountain folds at 6" & 17" along the length of the paper (measurements are from the base).

lines.text: Make the valley folds at 9" & 21" along the length of the paper (measurements are from the base).
lines.text_raw: Make the valley folds at 9" & 21" along the length of the paper (measurements are from the base).

lines.text: Lock the model
lines.text_raw: '''Lock the model'''

lines.text: At this point all 4 edges are open; let us close them.
lines.text_raw: At this point all 4 edges are open; let us close them.

lines.text: Now turn the paper over and valley-fold about 1" of the top and bottom edges.
lines.text_raw: Now turn the paper over and valley-fold about 1" of the top and bottom edges.

lines.text: For the right edge, valley-fold at an angle so that bottom part (2") is farther inside than the top part (1"). Repeat the same on the left edge.
lines.text_raw: For the right edge, valley-fold at an angle so that bottom part (2") is farther inside than the top part (1"). Repeat the same on the left edge.

lines.text: Crease firmly. While doing this the side edges will tend to go out, which is OK. This will give an extra bit of room in the pocket.
lines.text_raw: Crease firmly. While doing this the side edges will tend to go out, which is OK. This will give an extra bit of room in the pocket.

lines.text: You'll find the top corners falling outside the top edge line. Bring the corners inside by tucking them in.
lines.text_raw: You'll find the top corners falling outside the top edge line. Bring the corners inside by tucking them in.

lines.text: The letter holder is now ready and should look like an inverted trapezium.
lines.text_raw: The letter holder is now ready and should look like an inverted trapezium.

lines.text: Dimensions of the finished model are - Top length: 21"; Bottom length: 19"; Height: 13". [Note: folding the sides at an angle would give it some interesting shape rather than keeping it just a rectangle.]
lines.text_raw: Dimensions of the finished model are - Top length: 21"; Bottom length: 19"; Height: 13". [Note: folding the sides at an angle would give it some interesting shape rather than keeping it just a rectangle.]

lines.text: Stick it!
lines.text_raw: '''Stick it!'''

lines.text: Put some double-stick tape on the back side and stick it on the wall/door.
lines.text_raw: Put some double-stick tape on the back side and stick it on the wall/door.

lines.text: Your origami letter holder is ready for use!
lines.text_raw: Your origami letter holder is ready for use!
